title: Almost every balance problem traces back to the pros vs. pubs problem.
body:
Why does a champ get reworked?

Because they're too dominant in pubs but nowhere in pro play. (Or vice versa)

Why is the pro scene so cluttered with similar picks?

Because Riot makes consolation buffs/nerfs to make sure champs can still be played in pub play. 

Why are champs like Kalista, Azir and more considered design failures?

Because they can't fall on the spectrum of "Easy for anyone but hard to master" and are useless in PUB play yet dominant in pro play.

We're rapidly approaching the point (If we haven't already hit it) where Riot will need to make a call. To try and balance a game for bronze-to-gold or diamond plus. This half-measure of constantly trying to balance for everyone isn't working. We're already seeing the cracks with all these champions.

Almost a decade. We had a good run, but you can't keep playing half-n'-half here Riot.

...He can, but then he won't be bronze anymore.
The league community is in a sense known(okay well sort of known) for it's...Eh... insistence not to adapt to anything, the moment a bronze player is capable of something like this, he simply won't remain bronze for long.
Or silver, or gold, or even plat for that matter.

Hell let me give you one of my favorite examples: Back in season 6(approximately?) gromp and golems spawned earlier and didn't give much more exp to the jungler than others(before the jungle change that well, changed that), and so bot lane had a "tendency"(100% of the time in high level play) to start there, since if one side did them and the other didn't, it would pretty much auto-win the lane for them.

Now naturally it had a couple of effects:
1) Affected power of supports(and to a much lesser extent adcs), tanks would skip their weak earlier phases faster, could tank the camp better, and would take it down faster as well(part of the perks of being melee)
2) Affected the power junglers(If you NEEDED bot lane to clear that first camp, don't pick that champion).
3) Affected support itemization balancing(relic shield was particularly good here)

Now capitalizing on this advantage, and pulling it off(doing a short pve fight) was pretty trivial(you hit level 2 first and force a fight, if they back off you zone them from gold and exp, remember that you will hit level 3 first as well, and every time you have such a level advantage early game they can't even get near you), and yet it was pretty much never done below diamond, and rarely done in lower diamond, while eventually being nearly constantly done in high diamond+.

Other instances of this remind me of the "korean meta"(lane swap by default, that was before gromp/wraith was introduced), but the other servers just refused to budge.

The league community at this point has been cuddled beyond repair, they WON'T adapt, and you can't make them, they will cry until smashing their head into a brick wall will once again become a viable strategy.

I don't know how to freeze, for instance, and I'm sure I make macro mistakes every game that I don't even realize I'm making. Even if you don't believe anything I just said because it's biased or whatever, consider this. A lifetime videgame player, doggedly pursuing mastery on a handful of champions through hundreds of normal games. Objectively speaking, it would be pretty odd if, after all that, they were still bad at their champs, no? Perhaps you never learn the more nuanced aspects of the game playing like this, but you certainly can, at the very least, become proficient at your champion.

Surprisingly enough, I've seen counterexamples to this. I used to play the original CoD all the time, and eventually got _very_ good at it. Yet in that entire time, I saw some people pick the game up and reach a high skill level in a _very_ short time (read: maybe a year or 2 instead of the 4-5 it took me) and I saw others that improved some, and then seemed to 'flatline' and not get any better (I eventually surpassed those people), and I even saw a few people that played _all_ the time and yet never seemed to get any better.

The only explanation I can think of for these observations: A player's skill has an upper bound set by how they approach the game and learning it. Those who _bring their thinking caps_ and intend to learn things as they play will gradually improve but not in the smooth fashion that people imagine, rather, skill increases happen in fairly distinct steps contingent on the player mastering a new skill or technique and then learning how to apply it productively in game. Those who don't come as willing to learn, or feel that they have 'learned' the game will stop improving. They very best players are eternal students of the game, always learning. I myself had a pretty noticable and significant skill increase when I finally understood how to macro play effectively. I promptly went on a massive winning spree and increased my W-L diff by about over +20 in just 100 games. I noticed the caliber of play from the other players in my games increase over the course of that as well.

I'm not diamond skill level, and I never claimed to be. All I said was that its possible to be good on a champion if you have a low elo rank but primarily play normal games. That there are players who have sunk thousands of hours into this game and still suck doesn't disprove the existence of players who are skilled in some areas of the game but are unranked/low elo from mainly playing norms.

On Ekko specifically - it's not like a higher skilled player magically takes less damage than a lower-skilled player. A champion like Ekko, who has such tremendous damage and outplay potential in his kit, is more than capable of winning lane against an opponent who's a much higher rating than you. If you are experienced with landing the champion's abilities and know how much damage to expect, you can easily get solo kills against opponents in diamond. Such as this Taliyah, for example:

But the fact remains that if it were impossible for low-elo players to be good at their champs, the above situation would never happen, because they would fail every time. That it happens often enough for me to have match histories like those is proof that low elo players can be skilled at the champs they play.

I think the key to doing that is Riot has to stick to their guns on it and not budge if people whine. Riot should simply start making rules and guidelines for creating champs and item in general. Some champs are so overly complicated that once mastered, they don't truly have any real raw weaknesses and become infuriating to play around. Had they made any actual guidelines or rules for themselves, a lot of it would have probably been avoided straight from beginning.  Now were stuck with a shit ton of overloaded champs and riot has no idea how to balance anything anymore, so instead they simply overload everything in attempts at balancing the game. Almost like they're stuck in a catch-22.

They have an idea how to balance. The problem is that it's not enough in either direction. Champions who need tiny touches for solo queue but sledgehammers for pro play end up with the "happy medium" of a baseball bat. Which ends up not doing enough for either queue. 

There's also the fact that the rules are different for pro-and-pub play. Let's not pretend a champion like Kalista is going to be a bronze terror. Conversely, let's not joke that any Garen rework that keeps him mostly the same is suddenly going to catapult him into pro-play spotlight. 

Sadly, you can't "avoid" this problem. The inherent problem of trying to balance between two drastically different skill levels will show itself. It's only now, several years later when the skill disparity is higher than ever before, that we see the issue with pros vs. pubs. (Hell, I bet if you put Season 7 teams in Season 2, they'd smash EVERYONE. )

Had Riot created rules and guidelines to character creation and/or item creation, a lot could have been avoided. For instance; if riot decided that all champs should only have 1 passive and that If any champ has more than 1 passive then all champs shall have more than 1 passive; a guideline like this could've have avoided BS like Vayne having an added passive like Silverbolts to her kit or take perhaps the much hated Yasuo with his overloaded kit. A lot of issues stem from Riot having a lack of discipline to character/item creation. I understand character diversity, but we've come to the point that where if a champion isn't somewhat offering some form of complicated form of gameplay, whether it's Lucian to Thresh, they'll eventually lag behind as their kit is too old to continue, hence, champs like Garen, Mundo, fall behind while Ryze hits an all new high in character reworks. Such Guidelines could've forced Riot to make sure all champs/items remain relevant or at least more balanced.

My issue there is that it stifles design. Rules/Guidelines shouldn't be forever word-of-god-static-things because the game and players change. Especially in a game like League or DOTA. If you make a hard rule such as "You can only have one passive", it stifles design. The point here is that the design isn't what is at fault but the _balance_. (Just as a fun example, compare DOTA2's Sven or Wraith King to a hero like Ember Spirit or Earth Spirit. The difficulty scale is off the charts by comparison because the design evolved.)

The other issue is that when all gameplay is simple, you end up with even worse situations. Oh, sure, not for bronze-to-gold but for the highest echelon, you absolutely do. I've thought this for a while...

Why can't Riot make 2 separate states of balance? One for ranked, one for unranked?

I believe this is possible, just a lot of work. We know they can create different items and balances for different modes, which means they SHOULD be able to make 2 separate states of balance for ranked vs unranked.

Unranked would cater to lower Elo. Pub stompers like Yi would see nerfs; the harder to use champs would see buffs.

Ranked would be the opposite. It'd be balanced around pros-a champion not seeing any play there will get buffed. One who is picked every game gets nerfed, etc.

There's only 2 issues I can think of with this system. The first being the time it'd take to make 2 separate patches. Then again, this is the most popular video game in the world. I imagine Riot has some extra cash lying around that could go towards hiring a second balance team.

The other issue would be getting used to having separate balance patches in ranked and normals-which arguably could make practicing for ranked difficult. However the kits would remain the same-no reworks between the two, simply number buffs/nerfs in each to fit the environment it's going for.

I don't believe this would ever happen but I can't think of a good reason not to do it. Thoughts?
